feed.title: One Direction: A Boyband That Doesn't Do "Airgrabs"
feed.subtitle: One Direction are leading the charge of new boybands, but how do five pin-ups from across the pond stand out among this latest wave of pop and pretty haircuts?

link.title: One Direction: A Boyband That Doesn't Do "Airgrabs"

entry.title: One Direction: A Boyband That Doesn't Do "Airgrabs"

link.Abstract: One Direction are leading the charge of new boybands, but how do five pin-ups from across the pond stand out among this latest wave of pop and pretty haircuts?
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: They co-ordinate well, but One Direction doesn't necessarily do matching outfits. The English/Irish five-piece brings their UK hit album, Up All Night, to North America March 13.
link.title: One Direction

link.Abstract: Squee! Can't tell One Direction from The Wanted or Big Time Rush? Here's all you need to know about the new wave of boybands. (And if you already know all this stuff, please enjoy the oh-so dreamy pictures.)
link.title: Know Your Boybands!

link.Abstract: If you want photos of Adele looking adorable, you've come to the right place. The 2012 BRIT Awards went down in London Feb. 21. The show airs in Canada on MuchMusic, Feb. 21 at 8 p.m. Check out some of the highlights, with these pics of Rihanna, Coldplay, Kylie Minogue, Florence and the Machine and more.
link.title: Photos: 2012 BRIT Awards

content.div:
“We haven’t met any of the Canadian fans, yet. We’ve only seen a few ones as we were driving into the arena,” says One Direction’s Harry Styles from a lounge in the belly of Toronto’s Air Canada Centre, just hours after he arrived in Toronto, and only hours away from playing a sold-out show with tourmates Big Time Rush. The 18-year-old adds, “We’ll probably see some later on.”

Friends and self-identified Directioners: This would be an example of understatement.

As Styles and his One Direction bandmates Zayn Malik (19), Louis Tomlinson (20), Liam Payne (18), and Niall Horan (18) would discover the next day, “some” would be enough to shut down traffic in front of MuchMusic headquarters -- the spot where the English/Irish boyband delivered their first Canadian TV appearance. That same “some” continued to flit around Queen Street for hours afterward in their matching One Direction tees. (And sometime after that still, members of the “some” also mobilized at a downtown poutine joint recommended via the band’s Twitter.)

Since assembling on the 2010 season of the UK’s The X Factor -- five teenaged solo competitors later brought together Voltron-style by the show’s Simon Cowell and Nicole Scherzinger -- you’d think One Direction would be used to it. 1D (as per their tragically superficial-sounding pet name) has been embraced (screamed at?) by fans in their home countries, as well as Sweden and Italy (and that’s just what was documented in their TV documentary, One Direction: Year in the Making).

Their debut album, Up All Night, arrives in North America March 13 -- five months after it first debuted at No. 2 in the UK, but it’s nevertheless poised to lead a wave of acts engineered for maximum squeal-age. A new wave of boybands may be upon us -- One Direction and their comparatively more choreographed tourmates Big Time Rush being two of the more persuasive arguments. Simon Cowell, One Direction’s former X Factor mentor and current Syco record label boss, even told reporters last month that he’s aiming to find an American equivalent of his 1D boys for the US version of The X Factor.

As Styles notes, though, a burgeoning glut of boyband pop doesn’t necessarily mean the timing is right. “I think on paper the time is not right, because there’s a lot of boybands out there and stuff.”

What you need, then, is to do something different -- something that will stand above the tousled haircuts and matchy Topshop duds (though those things are certainly adorable).

Niall Horan, the Irish-born member of One Direction, offers his pitch: “People think that a boyband is air-grabs and [being] dressed in all one colour.” (For reference, please see any video from the early-2000s TRL era.) “We're boys in a band,” Horan continues. “We're trying to do something different. We're trying to do something different from what people would think is the typical kind of boyband. We're trying to do different kinds of music and we're just trying to be ourselves, not squeaky clean.”

Certainly, they’ve succeeded on the latter front. For the most part, that just means the group presents themselves as typical, goofy and uncensored teenage boys -- posting jokey YouTube videos, for instance, or boozing at awards shows. But they’re also more talented than any member of N*Sync or 98 Degrees when it comes to generating scandal worthy of a British tabloid. Styles made frequent headlines for his rumoured romance with TV presenter Caroline Flack, for instance. He was 17. She was 32.

As for the music, Up All Night is unabashed pop, with the occasional burst of guitar suggesting something more akin to pop-rock, in the Kelly Clarkson vein. (Incidentally, Clarkson gets a co-writing credit on album track “Tell Me a Lie.”) Their breakout hit, “What Makes You Beautiful” -- a summery tune that bested Adele’s “Someone Like You” to win best British single at this year’s BRITs -- is an ode to a girl who doesn’t know how pretty she is (could they be singing about you?!). It’s co-written by a trio who’ve all provided hits for some of the early aughts’ biggest boybands (Backstreet Boys, N*Sync, Westlife).

A follow-up album is already in development, Horan says. “In the summer, we’re going to get back and start a new record. We want to bring out a record nearly every year, every year and a half,” he says, revealing they’re already arranging “meetings and stuff with different writers and producers.”

That next disc, Horan and Styles say, will reflect more of their current tastes. Styles says his favourite music of the moment is being made by Foster the People, Coldplay, Kings of Leon (whom 1D cover in concert). Horan favours The Script, singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran, and “epic and drumsy” stuff. “We want to have a little bit heavier guitars, bigger drums, more of a live feel, because that’s what we like doing,” says Styles -- though he says that shouldn’t be misinterpreted to mean the group is going “grungier.”

“I like bands,” says Styles -- but that includes the boyband sound of One Direction.

“Because we are 18 years old, it's important that we like what we're doing as well,” says Styles. “It wouldn't be good if we weren't enjoying what we're doing, and we are.”

Up All Night arrives in North America March 13.

leahc@dose.ca

link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
Adele offers a comedic "gesture" to the camera after being cut off in the middle of her acceptance speech. The biggest pop star in the world -- we repeat, the biggest pop star in the world -- was interrupted while accepting the BRIT Award for album of the year.
Adele: "You're going to cut me off?"
Host, James Corden: "I'm so sorry."
Adele: "Can I just say, then, goodbye and I'll see you next time 'round, yeah?" (Flips her middle finger.)
link.title: Adele offers a comedic "gesture" to the camera after being cut off in the middle of her acceptance speech.
